snippet: Gabriel García Márquez — who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87 — used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction.
abstract: Michiko Kakutani appraisal of author Gabriel Garcia Marquez, who died at his home in Mexico City at the age of 87, noting he used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction; cites his all-embracing artistic vision that recognized the extraordinary in the mundane, and the familiar in the fantastic.
lead_paragraph: Gabriel García Márquez — who died on Thursday at his home in Mexico City, at the age of 87 — used his fecund imagination and exuberant sleight of hand to conjure the miraculous in his fiction.

headline.print_headline: Entwining Tales of Time, Memory and Love
headline.seo: The Work of Gabriel García Márquez
headline.main: Entwining Tales of Time, Memory and Love
